definition: to buy tickets/(Tw) to buy votes (in an election)
ticket/ballot/banknote/CL:張|张[zhang1]/person held for ransom/amateur performance of Chinese opera/classifier for groups, batches, business transactions

sentences.english: Even if I was the most swift-footed, I didn't have enough money to go!
sentences.chinese: 儘管我比誰都先到，但是我沒有那麼多錢買票。

sentences.english: Once having left the museum, you must buy another ticket to re-renter.
sentences.chinese: 一旦離開了博物館，你就必須再次買票才能進入。

sentences.english: The football fans lined up for the tickets.
Three people me while I was waiting in ine to buy the ticket.
sentences.chinese: 當我排隊買票的時候，三個年輕人插到了我的前面。

sentences.english: Cao, after buying guide took us enter the fingerprint on the ticket to enter the forest park.
sentences.chinese: 曹導買票後我們拿了票輸入指紋就進入森林公園。

sentences.english: Why do we buy a ticket?
Then, the ticket, Xiao-Ding under a single.
sentences.chinese: 於是，買票的時候，小丁就多下了一張單。

sentences.english: By the way, does my boy/girl need to buy a ticket?
sentences.chinese: 順便問下，我的孩子需要買票嗎？

sentences.english: He recalls that there was a long queue outside the ticket office everyday as people lined up to buy tickets.
sentences.chinese: 每一天，買票的人們都在售票處外排起了長隊。

sentences.english: You can buy a ticket on the train from the ticket inspector.
sentences.chinese: 你可以在火車上向查票員買票。

sentences.english: Please keep my suitcase while I leave for a ticket.
sentences.chinese: 我去買票時請替我保管一下手提箱。

sentences.english: Concerning World Cup tickets, Khoza acknowledged that the process of buying tickets was cumbersome.
sentences.chinese: 官員世界盃門票，科扎說買票的過程有些緩慢複雜。

sentences.english: Only those under 16 years old can register their residence to buy tickets.
sentences.chinese: 只有小於16歲的孩子能登記並買票。

sentences.english: I bought the ticket while he watched over the luggages.
sentences.chinese: 我買票，他忙著照看行李。

sentences.english: You can get tickets from the automats.
sentences.chinese: 你可以在自動售票機買票。

sentences.english: Even over the train station turnstiles to pay for rides.
sentences.chinese: 甚至能夠在火車站旋轉柵欄買票。

definition: to get on or into (a bus, train, car etc)
(to take) a turn for the better/to change planes
to set off/to start (on a journey)
to agree/to conclude/to draw up/to subscribe to (a newspaper etc)/to order
to cross a barrier/to get through (an ordeal)/to pass (a test)/to reach (a standard)
to place an order/to book ahead
